Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS Collaborative Research: Untangling the Passionflower Vines: Phylogeny, Species Diversification, and Character Evolution in Passiflora Subg. Decaloba (Passifloraceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Passiflora represents a diverse group of more than 560 species of vines and trees primarily found in Central and South America. These plants are best known as the source of tropical passionfruit, but are also widely cultivated for their beautiful, complex flowers. Passionflowers appear to be a recently-evolved lineage that has experienced rapid species diversification. Many species are poorly understood with regard to morphology, geographical distribution, and conservation status, especially in the largest lineage of passionflowers, subgenus Decaloba, with 235+ species. This study will synthesize modern and traditional approaches to address these problems, using DNA sequence data, scanning electron microscopy, and observation of fresh and preserved specimens. Field work will enable collection of fresh material and documentation of species distributions. This project will yield a revision of all species in Decaloba, and will provide a modern evolutionary framework within which to address questions about the evolution of floral shape, pollination syndromes, floral development, and the biogeographical history of the lineage.

This study will address important biological and evolutionary questions in an especially charismatic group of plants. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the research. Undergraduates at Keene State College and Harris-Stowe State University, institutions that primarily enroll underrepresented groups in the sciences, will especially benefit from involvement in this study. Summer workshops at Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden will involve students from the local community. Field expeditions will build international collaborations among U.S. scientists and colleagues in Mexico, Central America, and South America. All results of this project will be available through a website hosted by the Missouri Botanical Garden.

Title of project: REVSYS Collaborative Research: Untangling the passionflower vines:
phylogeny, species diversification, and character evolution in Passiflora subg. Decaloba (Passifloraceae)
    The passionflowers, genus Passiflora, were described in 1753 by Linneaus, known from 20 species. We are still in the process of learning about this fascinating group which includes species cultivated for delicious fruit, and we are rapidly discovering distinctive new species previously unknown to science; the total now stands around 585 species of passionflower vine. The genus has been understood as composed of five major lineages: two very large groups, the subgenera Passiflora (250 species) and Decaloba (250 spp.), and three smaller subgenera, Astrophea (58 spp.), Deidamioides (14 spp.), and Tetrapathaea (3 spp.). Almost all passionflowers are found in the New World (NW) from the USA to Argentina with a few exceptions. The subgenus Tetrapathaea is from Australia, New Zealand, and Papua New Guinea and a group of about 20 species from the subgenus Decaloba is also found in the Old World (OW) in Australia, SE Asia, China, and India.
    This study aimed to elucidate the main genetic lineages and evolutionary history of Passiflora subgenus Decaloba (the small-flowered passionflowers), gaining knowledge of the important characters that describe and characterize the different evolutionary lineages, provide an updated revision and monograph to the species of Decaloba, and find information that would help conserve the hundreds of species in the wild. Research and training opportunities for undergraduates, particularly underserved minority students, were also provided over several years through this grant work.
    A major scientific article summarizing our findings was finished and in press in the autumn of 2012 in the journal Systematic Botany. Results indicate that the OW subgenus Tetrapathaea is sister to the NW Decaloba, and that the few other OW species arose from a separate later dispersal event. The main groups or bloodlines inside subgenus Decaloba were described and confirmed. Rearrangement of species is needed in a number of groups, indicating that some characters used traditionally are of less importance while other previously thought to be unimportant are in reality informative. A large previously unrecognized lineage was discovered that can be recognized by the simple lack (evolutionary loss) of extrafloral nectaries.
    Our monographic work is based on approximately 33,000 dried specimens from 18,000 collections, as well thousands of color photographs of the species. We established a database to capture information from the collections housed in approximately 150 museums worldwide, and established a research image database. For each herbarium specimen we can store 500 variables or observations pertaining to each individual collection. Decisions are made as to which specimens belong to which species, and the descriptions are both prepared from and stored in our database.
